  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
    --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
    --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
    color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /** Converts a <button> to look like an <a> tag. */
  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;
    background: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
  }
  h1, h2, h3, h4 {
    background: none;
  }
  a, chops-button, a.button, .button, .linkify {
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;
    font-weight: var(--chops-link-font-weight);
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);
  }
  chops-button i.material-icons, a.button i.material-icons, .button i.material-icons {
    display: block;
    margin-right: 4px;
  }
  chops-button.emphasized, a.button.emphasized, .button.emphasized {
    background: var(--chops-primary-button-bg);
    color: var(--chops-primary-button-color);
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }
  .medium-heading chops-button {
    line-height: 1.6;
  }
  .input-grid {
    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        mr-app {
          display: block;
          padding-top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-top: -1px; /* Prevent a double border from showing up. */

          /* From shared-styles.js. */
          --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
          --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
          --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
          font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
          color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
        }
        main {
          border-top: var(--chops-normal-border);
        }
        .snackbar-container {
          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }

          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.

          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.

    <mr-cue centered="" cueprefname="search_for_numbers" hidden=""></mr-cue>
      
          
      
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>

      <div class="select-container">

      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by markr...@gmail.com (Jul 7, 2021)
      </option>

      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>This exploit allows a malicious webpage containing a HTML form to read values that are being proposed by Chrome's autocomplete feature before the user has actually selected them (i.e. while the autocomplete UI is open and in the "suggest"/"preview" state).<span class="line"><!---->This exploit allows a malicious webpage containing a HTML form to read values that are being proposed by Chrome's autocomplete feature before the user has actually selected them (i.e. while the autocomplete UI is open and in the "suggest"/"preview" state).<!----></span><br><br>In this way, it is similar to the following exploits I've reported previously:<span class="line"><!---->In this way, it is similar to the following exploits I've reported previously:<!----></span><br>* <span class="line"><!---->* <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=916838<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=916838"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=916838<!----></a><br>* <span class="line"><!---->* <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=951487<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=951487"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=951487<!----></a><br>* <span class="line"><!---->* <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1013882<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1013882"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1013882<!----></a><br>* <span class="line"><!---->* <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035058<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035058"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035058<!----></a><br>* <span class="line"><!---->* <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035063<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035063"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035063<!----></a><br><br>As a reminder of the feature and its security model: Chrome's form autocompletion includes rendering suggested values inside the form fields while the user is hovering over possible autocomplete options or scrolling through them with the keyboard, but these values are *not* exposed via the .value property on those fields and are not supposed to be readable by the web page until the user commits a suggestion to the field (by clicking on it or pressing the Enter key).<span class="line"><!---->As a reminder of the feature and its security model: Chrome's form autocompletion includes rendering suggested values inside the form fields while the user is hovering over possible autocomplete options or scrolling through them with the keyboard, but these values are *not* exposed via the .value property on those fields and are not supposed to be readable by the web page until the user commits a suggestion to the field (by clicking on it or pressing the Enter key).<!----></span><br><br>I've included a demo below that - like my previous demos - reads the user's credit card number as soon as they press the up or down arrow key. Thus minimal social engineering is required - just lure them to a page and get them to press one key, and you have their card number. The approach used could in principle be extended to other autocomplete data, although the limited alphabet (digits only) of card numbers makes them particularly easy targets.<span class="line"><!---->I've included a demo below that - like my previous demos - reads the user's credit card number as soon as they press the up or down arrow key. Thus minimal social engineering is required - just lure them to a page and get them to press one key, and you have their card number. The approach used could in principle be extended to other autocomplete data, although the limited alphabet (digits only) of card numbers makes them particularly easy targets.<!----></span><br><br>Below I'll list the bugs and tactics that contribute to the final demo.<span class="line"><!---->Below I'll list the bugs and tactics that contribute to the final demo.<!----></span><br><br>Bug 1<span class="line"><!---->Bug 1<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>(remaining scrollWidth data leak in "suggest" state):<span class="line"><!---->(remaining scrollWidth data leak in "suggest" state):<!----></span><br><br>Although the fix to <span class="line"><!---->Although the fix to <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035058<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035058"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035058<!----></a> attempted to mock scrollWidth on textareas in the "suggest" state so that no information about the width of the suggestion content would be leaked to JavaScript, it didn't completely succeed; the scrollWidth value returned for a textarea with a given width depends upon whether it contains a vertical scrollbar.<span class="line"><!----> attempted to mock scrollWidth on textareas in the "suggest" state so that no information about the width of the suggestion content would be leaked to JavaScript, it didn't completely succeed; the scrollWidth value returned for a textarea with a given width depends upon whether it contains a vertical scrollbar.<!----></span><br><br>This immediately allows two tactics:<span class="line"><!---->This immediately allows two tactics:<!----></span><br><br>Tactic 1 (suggestion text appearance detection):<span class="line"><!---->Tactic 1 (suggestion text appearance detection):<!----></span><br><br>In a form where Chrome will fill suggestion text, include a tiny (e.g. 5px by 1px) textarea with autocomplete enabled. Record its initial scrollWidth into a variable when the page loads, then check its scrollWidth constantly (e.g. via a setInterval). When it changes, this indicates that a vertical scrollbar has appeared in the field, which in turn indicates that suggestion text has appeared in the field (and hence also in other fields that get autocompleted simultaneously).<span class="line"><!---->In a form where Chrome will fill suggestion text, include a tiny (e.g. 5px by 1px) textarea with autocomplete enabled. Record its initial scrollWidth into a variable when the page loads, then check its scrollWidth constantly (e.g. via a setInterval). When it changes, this indicates that a vertical scrollbar has appeared in the field, which in turn indicates that suggestion text has appeared in the field (and hence also in other fields that get autocompleted simultaneously).<!----></span><br><br>Tactic 2 (vertical scrollbar detection):<span class="line"><!---->Tactic 2 (vertical scrollbar detection):<!----></span><br><br>In the form where autocomplete is happening, include a textarea that has autocomplete enabled, is tall and wide, and is limited via the maxlength attribute to containing 1 character. Since it is big and can only have one character of content, it can be assumed to never contain a scrollbar. When it contains suggestion text (which can be detected via Tactic 1), calculate the difference between its offsetWidth and scrollWidth and store it in a variable.<span class="line"><!---->In the form where autocomplete is happening, include a textarea that has autocomplete enabled, is tall and wide, and is limited via the maxlength attribute to containing 1 character. Since it is big and can only have one character of content, it can be assumed to never contain a scrollbar. When it contains suggestion text (which can be detected via Tactic 1), calculate the difference between its offsetWidth and scrollWidth and store it in a variable.<!----></span><br><br>To determine whether some other textarea in the preview state has a vertical scrollbar, compute the difference between its offsetWidth and scrollWidth and check whether it is equal to the already-computed difference from the textarea known to have no scrollbar. If it is different, then the textarea has a vertical scrollbar.<span class="line"><!---->To determine whether some other textarea in the preview state has a vertical scrollbar, compute the difference between its offsetWidth and scrollWidth and check whether it is equal to the already-computed difference from the textarea known to have no scrollbar. If it is different, then the textarea has a vertical scrollbar.<!----></span><br><br>Tactic 3 (suggestion text width measuring):<span class="line"><!---->Tactic 3 (suggestion text width measuring):<!----></span><br><br>As long as suggestion text in a textarea is more than 1 character long, its width can be measured by setting its height to just barely above the height of one line of text (so that text spilling over to a second line will cause a vertical scrollbar will appear) and its width to 1px, then increasing the width by 1px at a time and using vertical scrollbar detection after each increase. When the vertical scrollbar vanishes, the width the textarea has been set to is equal to the width of the suggestion text.<span class="line"><!---->As long as suggestion text in a textarea is more than 1 character long, its width can be measured by setting its height to just barely above the height of one line of text (so that text spilling over to a second line will cause a vertical scrollbar will appear) and its width to 1px, then increasing the width by 1px at a time and using vertical scrollbar detection after each increase. When the vertical scrollbar vanishes, the width the textarea has been set to is equal to the width of the suggestion text.<!----></span><br><br>Tactic 4 (per-character suggestion text width measuring):<span class="line"><!---->Tactic 4 (per-character suggestion text width measuring):<!----></span><br><br>The widths of the third character and onward of suggestion text in an autocomplete form can be measured by creating a series of textareas with increasing maxlength attributes, starting at 2 and going up by 1 each time, all set to autocomplete to the same value, and then using Tactic 3 on each of them. The width of e.g. the fifth character is then the difference in width between the content in the textarea with maxlength=4 and the content in the textarea with maxlength=5.<span class="line"><!---->The widths of the third character and onward of suggestion text in an autocomplete form can be measured by creating a series of textareas with increasing maxlength attributes, starting at 2 and going up by 1 each time, all set to autocomplete to the same value, and then using Tactic 3 on each of them. The width of e.g. the fifth character is then the difference in width between the content in the textarea with maxlength=4 and the content in the textarea with maxlength=5.<!----></span><br><br>Bug 2<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=2" title="Testing if chromium id works"><!---->Bug 2<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>(fixing of font for autocomplete text can be bypassed):<span class="line"><!---->(fixing of font for autocomplete text can be bypassed):<!----></span><br><br>Although the fix to <span class="line"><!---->Although the fix to <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035058<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035058"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1035058<!----></a> attempted to fix the `font` CSS property of preview text in a way that couldn't be overridden by CSS on the webpage, it didn't quite manage to do that either; the font of the first line can still be modified by CSS targeting the textarea's ::first-line pseudo-element.<span class="line"><!----> attempted to fix the `font` CSS property of preview text in a way that couldn't be overridden by CSS on the webpage, it didn't quite manage to do that either; the font of the first line can still be modified by CSS targeting the textarea's ::first-line pseudo-element.<!----></span><br><br>Tactic 5 (determining the third and subsequent characters of suggestion text):<span class="line"><!---->Tactic 5 (determining the third and subsequent characters of suggestion text):<!----></span><br><br>Combining <span class="line"><!---->Combining <!----></span>bug 2<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=2" title="Testing if chromium id works"><!---->bug 2<!----></a> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> tactic 4 lets us determine what the third and subsequent characters are in preview text. We just generate a custom font where each character has a distinct width, then use <span class="line"><!----> tactic 4 lets us determine what the third and subsequent characters are in preview text. We just generate a custom font where each character has a distinct width, then use <!----></span>bug 2<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=2" title="Testing if chromium id works"><!---->bug 2<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>to set that font on each of the textareas described in tactic 4. Then we execute tactic 4 and map from the signature character widths back to the characters.<span class="line"><!---->to set that font on each of the textareas described in tactic 4. Then we execute tactic 4 and map from the signature character widths back to the characters.<!----></span><br><br>Tactic 6 (font choice conditional on suggestion text):<span class="line"><!---->Tactic 6 (font choice conditional on suggestion text):<!----></span><br><br>By declaring a font-family using a series of font-face declarations that each include a unicode-range descriptor (<span class="line"><!---->By declaring a font-family using a series of font-face declarations that each include a unicode-range descriptor (<!----></span>https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@font-face/unicode-range<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@font-face/unicode-range"><!---->https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@font-face/unicode-range<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> limiting them to a single character, then setting it on a textarea's suggestion text by targeting ::first-line as described in <span class="line"><!----> limiting them to a single character, then setting it on a textarea's suggestion text by targeting ::first-line as described in <!----></span>Bug 2<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=2" title="Testing if chromium id works"><!---->Bug 2<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>you can make the font(s) used depend on the character(s) in the suggestion text. This can be exploited either to trigger HTTP requests (to load the fonts) conditionally based on suggestion text, or to implement tactic 8, below...<span class="line"><!---->you can make the font(s) used depend on the character(s) in the suggestion text. This can be exploited either to trigger HTTP requests (to load the fonts) conditionally based on suggestion text, or to implement tactic 8, below...<!----></span><br><br>Tactic 7 (suggestion text height measuring):<span class="line"><!---->Tactic 7 (suggestion text height measuring):<!----></span><br><br>Use the same approach as tactic 3, but gradually increasing the textarea's *height* (instead of its width). When the vertical scrollbar disappears, the textarea is tall enough to hold all its content.<span class="line"><!---->Use the same approach as tactic 3, but gradually increasing the textarea's *height* (instead of its width). When the vertical scrollbar disappears, the textarea is tall enough to hold all its content.<!----></span><br><br>Tactic 8 (determining the first character of suggestion text):<span class="line"><!---->Tactic 8 (determining the first character of suggestion text):<!----></span><br><br>Create a textarea limited to a maxlength of 1. Use tactic 6 to set make its font be conditionally chosen based on the character it contains, with the possible fonts all having distinct line heights (for instance by giving them increasingly large "ascender" and "descender" values, in the case of TrueType fonts; I'm not sure whether there are other ways to achieve the same thing or whether the ascender/descender concept exists for all font types).  When the textarea is filled with suggestion content (detected by Tactic 1), measure the height of that content (using tactic 7). Then map that height back to the font that was used and hence the character that is contained in the suggestion text.<span class="line"><!---->Create a textarea limited to a maxlength of 1. Use tactic 6 to set make its font be conditionally chosen based on the character it contains, with the possible fonts all having distinct line heights (for instance by giving them increasingly large "ascender" and "descender" values, in the case of TrueType fonts; I'm not sure whether there are other ways to achieve the same thing or whether the ascender/descender concept exists for all font types).  When the textarea is filled with suggestion content (detected by Tactic 1), measure the height of that content (using tactic 7). Then map that height back to the font that was used and hence the character that is contained in the suggestion text.<!----></span><br><br>-----<span class="line"><!---->-----<!----></span><br><br>The overall exploit strategy thus looks like this:<span class="line"><!---->The overall exploit strategy thus looks like this:<!----></span><br>* Create a page with a credit card form (which can be hidden behind other content) with one autofocused autocomplete <input> and lots of autocomplete <textarea>s that are configured to support the tactics described above.<span class="line"><!---->* Create a page with a credit card form (which can be hidden behind other content) with one autofocused autocomplete &lt;input&gt; and lots of autocomplete &lt;textarea&gt;s that are configured to support the tactics described above.<!----></span><br>* Lure a user to it and induce them to press the up or down arrow key, immediately putting autocomplete suggestion text into the textareas<span class="line"><!---->* Lure a user to it and induce them to press the up or down arrow key, immediately putting autocomplete suggestion text into the textareas<!----></span><br>* Via tactic 1, the page detects and reacts to the appearance of the suggestion text. It executes tactic 8 to determine the first digit of their credit card number, executes tactic 5 to determine digits 3-16 of their credit card number, and then infers the second digit by picking the value that passes the Luhn check.<span class="line"><!---->* Via tactic 1, the page detects and reacts to the appearance of the suggestion text. It executes tactic 8 to determine the first digit of their credit card number, executes tactic 5 to determine digits 3-16 of their credit card number, and then infers the second digit by picking the value that passes the Luhn check.<!----></span><br>* (Then if this was being used for real the page would send the card number off via a HTTP request to bad people who would use it for fraud etc)<span class="line"><!---->* (Then if this was being used for real the page would send the card number off via a HTTP request to bad people who would use it for fraud etc)<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 92.0.4515.80 beta<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 92.0.4515.80 beta<!----></span><br>Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>Host the attached demo.html and various .js files on a HTTPS webserver. Visit demo.html from an install of Chrome where you have a Luhn-passing 16-digit credit card number stored in autocomplete (but NOT in Google Pay - for some reason the autocomplete preview text shown for a card number stored in Google Pay is *not* the card number itself, which defeats this attack). Press the up or down arrow key and your card number should appear in an alert.<span class="line"><!---->Host the attached demo.html and various .js files on a HTTPS webserver. Visit demo.html from an install of Chrome where you have a Luhn-passing 16-digit credit card number stored in autocomplete (but NOT in Google Pay - for some reason the autocomplete preview text shown for a card number stored in Google Pay is *not* the card number itself, which defeats this attack). Press the up or down arrow key and your card number should appear in an alert.<!----></span><br><br>Note that I've tested on Ubuntu but not in other OSes.<span class="line"><!---->Note that I've tested on Ubuntu but not in other OSes.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Mark Amery<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Mark Amery<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I cannot reproduce the problem (my digits3To16 are [-9, 11, 1, 1, -17, 19, 1, -23, 25, 1, 1, -31, 33, 1]) but I can imagine that something like this works (even though I don't fully understand all steps of the attack, yet).<span class="line"><!---->I cannot reproduce the problem (my digits3To16 are [-9, 11, 1, 1, -17, 19, 1, -23, 25, 1, 1, -31, 33, 1]) but I can imagine that something like this works (even though I don't fully understand all steps of the attack, yet).<!----></span><br><br>@futhark, @masonf, tkent@ do you see any reliable way to fix the problems on the renderer side?<span class="line"><!---->@futhark, @masonf, tkent@ do you see any reliable way to fix the problems on the renderer side?<!----></span><br><br>1) The scrollHeight calculation was moved in this CL <span class="line"><!---->1) The scrollHeight calculation was moved in this CL <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2488963<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2488963"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2488963<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span> Would it make sense if HTMLTextAreaElement::scrollHeight() and HTMLInputElement::scrollHeight() received their own implementations in case the elements are in preview state rather than delegating to TextControlElement::scrollHeight() (which is Element::scrollHeight())<span class="line"><!----> Would it make sense if HTMLTextAreaElement::scrollHeight() and HTMLInputElement::scrollHeight() received their own implementations in case the elements are in preview state rather than delegating to TextControlElement::scrollHeight() (which is Element::scrollHeight())<!----></span><br><br>2) Do you see a way of more reliably overriding the text style? It looks like <span class="line"><!---->2) Do you see a way of more reliably overriding the text style? It looks like <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/html/resources/html.css;l=580;drc=bad2e8cbbeaed94546a41bc715a6263650555254<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/html/resources/html.css;l=580;drc=bad2e8cbbeaed94546a41bc715a6263650555254"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/html/resources/html.css;l=580;drc=bad2e8cbbeaed94546a41bc715a6263650555254<!----></a> is insufficient and can be overridden with textarea::first-line.<span class="line"><!----> is insufficient and can be overridden with textarea::first-line.<!----></span><br><br>3) I can see a relatively straightforward approach of mitigating the problem by showing "**** **** **** 1111" instead of "4111 1111 1111 1111" as a preview state. We do this for cards from GPay as well.<span class="line"><!---->3) I can see a relatively straightforward approach of mitigating the problem by showing "**** **** **** 1111" instead of "4111 1111 1111 1111" as a preview state. We do this for cards from GPay as well.<!----></span><br><br>I think that 3) would get us pretty far but I would also like the last 4 digits to be not discoverable.<span class="line"><!---->I think that 3) would get us pretty far but I would also like the last 4 digits to be not discoverable.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The other thing with 3), of course, is that it only protects card numbers specifically. I've always targeted card numbers so far because only having to deal with 10 possible characters and no spaces makes these attacks a bit simpler to implement, but other autofill fields (like someone's home address) are also vulnerable in theory to the same exploit, and also potentially serious to leak.<span class="line"><!---->The other thing with 3), of course, is that it only protects card numbers specifically. I've always targeted card numbers so far because only having to deal with 10 possible characters and no spaces makes these attacks a bit simpler to implement, but other autofill fields (like someone's home address) are also vulnerable in theory to the same exploit, and also potentially serious to leak.<!----></span><br><br>Sorry to hear that the demo didn't work for you. I have a couple of ideas that might get it working for you:<span class="line"><!---->Sorry to hear that the demo didn't work for you. I have a couple of ideas that might get it working for you:<!----></span><br>* try setting and unsetting a .value on textAreas[0] when the page loads to force the custom font to load into memory immediately, like I do with firstDigitTester.value = '1234567890';.<span class="line"><!---->* try setting and unsetting a .value on textAreas[0] when the page loads to force the custom font to load into memory immediately, like I do with firstDigitTester.value = '1234567890';.<!----></span><br>* make findContentWidthOfPreviewText be an async function, await it at the place where it's called, and stick an `await timeout(1)` after each assignment to textArea.style.width<span class="line"><!---->* make findContentWidthOfPreviewText be an async function, await it at the place where it's called, and stick an `await timeout(1)` after each assignment to textArea.style.width<!----></span><br><br>(The latter suggested change makes the attack less good, since it makes it slower and interruptible by the user, but might suffice let you see at least a toy version of it working.)<span class="line"><!---->(The latter suggested change makes the attack less good, since it makes it slower and interruptible by the user, but might suffice let you see at least a toy version of it working.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 19<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1227170#c19">Comment 19<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">

        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        After some thought, my instinct is that any solution that still leaves the values in the Shadow DOM is going to still be vulnerable to some kind of attack. For instance, here's another idea I had a couple of days ago: use text fragments (<span class="line"><!---->After some thought, my instinct is that any solution that still leaves the values in the Shadow DOM is going to still be vulnerable to some kind of attack. For instance, here's another idea I had a couple of days ago: use text fragments (<!----></span>https://wicg.github.io/scroll-to-text-fragment/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://wicg.github.io/scroll-to-text-fragment/"><!---->https://wicg.github.io/scroll-to-text-fragment/<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> that target a string you're looking for in the preview text and then check whether the page scrolled. It seems that text fragments can indeed target suggestion text, and that you can change the URL fragment via JavaScript and such a change will trigger the page to scroll to the targeted text if it's present. Finally you can detect the scroll happening by polling window.scrollY.<span class="line"><!----> that target a string you're looking for in the preview text and then check whether the page scrolled. It seems that text fragments can indeed target suggestion text, and that you can change the URL fragment via JavaScript and such a change will trigger the page to scroll to the targeted text if it's present. Finally you can detect the scroll happening by polling window.scrollY.<!----></span><br><br>Apparently an attack similar to this was contemplated when text fragments were implemented - see "scroll-based attack" at <span class="line"><!---->Apparently an attack similar to this was contemplated when text fragments were implemented - see "scroll-based attack" at <!----></span>https://docs.google.com/document/d/1YHcl1-vE_ZnZ0kL2almeikAj2gkwCq8_5xwIae7PVik/edit#<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1YHcl1-vE_ZnZ0kL2almeikAj2gkwCq8_5xwIae7PVik/edit#"><!---->https://docs.google.com/document/d/1YHcl1-vE_ZnZ0kL2almeikAj2gkwCq8_5xwIae7PVik/edit#<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span> There, though, they're contemplating attacks involving somehow detecting scrolling happening in another frame from a different origin. It doesn't seem to have been on their radar that there could be content within shadow DOMs *in the current frame* that needs to be secret too.<span class="line"><!----> There, though, they're contemplating attacks involving somehow detecting scrolling happening in another frame from a different origin. It doesn't seem to have been on their radar that there could be content within shadow DOMs *in the current frame* that needs to be secret too.<!----></span><br><br>Chrome seems to limit text fragments to targeting full words, not partial words, as a mitigation against this kind of attack. In this case though, I don't think that offers any help, since we can use maxlength on textareas to limit how much of the suggestion gets included in the DOM in the first place; then some subset of the card number IS a full word.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome seems to limit text fragments to targeting full words, not partial words, as a mitigation against this kind of attack. In this case though, I don't think that offers any help, since we can use maxlength on textareas to limit how much of the suggestion gets included in the DOM in the first place; then some subset of the card number IS a full word.<!----></span><br><br>Thus this technique should give us an entirely new mechanism to repeatedly query for prefixes of the card number and find out whether they're present. Once we can do that, of course, the rest of the logic of the attack is exactly like this one and the previous five I've opened: first use the mechanism to find the first character, then repeatedly test possible one-character extensions to the currently-known prefix until you've got all 16 digits.<span class="line"><!---->Thus this technique should give us an entirely new mechanism to repeatedly query for prefixes of the card number and find out whether they're present. Once we can do that, of course, the rest of the logic of the attack is exactly like this one and the previous five I've opened: first use the mechanism to find the first character, then repeatedly test possible one-character extensions to the currently-known prefix until you've got all 16 digits.<!----></span><br><br>So what's the right fix, then?<span class="line"><!---->So what's the right fix, then?<!----></span><br><br>tkent earlier suggested using something called FrameOverlay to show these values, which per his comment is apparently what the dev tools do. I'm not a Chrome dev and have never heard of a FrameOverlay until now, but I assume that this would get the content out of the shadow DOM, and if so, it sounds like it's probably the right thing to do here and a much more robust fix than tinkering with the styling of the shadow DOM.<span class="line"><!---->tkent earlier suggested using something called FrameOverlay to show these values, which per his comment is apparently what the dev tools do. I'm not a Chrome dev and have never heard of a FrameOverlay until now, but I assume that this would get the content out of the shadow DOM, and if so, it sounds like it's probably the right thing to do here and a much more robust fix than tinkering with the styling of the shadow DOM.<!----></span><br><br>A bonus would be if there's a reasonable and non-leaky way to explicitly make the text shown in that FrameOverlay respect a subset of the font styling CSS properties that are applied to the input or textarea that spawned it, especially the font-size. That way, as well as fixing the security hole once and for all, you could also fix or mitigate the aesthetic issues that have been caused by forcing preview text to be a different font size from real form text. Those aesthetic issues upset a lot of people (see <span class="line"><!---->A bonus would be if there's a reasonable and non-leaky way to explicitly make the text shown in that FrameOverlay respect a subset of the font styling CSS properties that are applied to the input or textarea that spawned it, especially the font-size. That way, as well as fixing the security hole once and for all, you could also fix or mitigate the aesthetic issues that have been caused by forcing preview text to be a different font size from real form text. Those aesthetic issues upset a lot of people (see <!----></span>https://stackoverflow.com/q/56271193/1709587<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://stackoverflow.com/q/56271193/1709587"><!---->https://stackoverflow.com/q/56271193/1709587<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>https://stackoverflow.com/q/56026043/1709587<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://stackoverflow.com/q/56026043/1709587"><!---->https://stackoverflow.com/q/56026043/1709587<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=953689<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=953689"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=953689<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span> The only thing to cautious about here is font-familys that point to custom fonts, due to the kind of leaks I described in tactic 6 above. Even just respecting font-size would be a big step up in aesthetics, though!<span class="line"><!----> The only thing to cautious about here is font-familys that point to custom fonts, due to the kind of leaks I described in tactic 6 above. Even just respecting font-size would be a big step up in aesthetics, though!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1227170#c22">Comment 22<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Jul 23, 2021, 1:36 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1227170#c22">Comment 22<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Jul 23, 2021, 1:36 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>

          Cc:<strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          pdr@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          pdr@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        And now I'd like to say this:<span class="line"><!---->And now I'd like to say this:<!----></span><br><br>I believe you're correct that FrameOverlay will paint "on top" of everything else. +pdr@ to confirm.<span class="line"><!---->I believe you're correct that FrameOverlay will paint "on top" of everything else. +pdr@ to confirm.<!----></span><br><br>I do see your point that using Shadow DOM as we are here automatically gets around a number of sticky issues. Shadow DOM is intended to isolate styles, so it should at least be a good starting point for this use case. The issue is that a number of properties inherit, or otherwise affect rendering, of shadow-isolated content. And there are a number of pseudo elements that also have the power to style into shadow roots. Short of making sure to explicitly style all of those in the UA stylesheet, I'm not sure there's a good way to isolate them all.<span class="line"><!---->I do see your point that using Shadow DOM as we are here automatically gets around a number of sticky issues. Shadow DOM is intended to isolate styles, so it should at least be a good starting point for this use case. The issue is that a number of properties inherit, or otherwise affect rendering, of shadow-isolated content. And there are a number of pseudo elements that also have the power to style into shadow roots. Short of making sure to explicitly style all of those in the UA stylesheet, I'm not sure there's a good way to isolate them all.<!----></span><br><br>One idea, which I'm not sure would work here, would be to use `contain:strict` on the shadow roots created for this purpose. I would think that should keep any CSS adjustments from outside from affecting at least the dimensions of the outer element, and that seems to be the vector for information leakage in all of these cases.<span class="line"><!---->One idea, which I'm not sure would work here, would be to use `contain:strict` on the shadow roots created for this purpose. I would think that should keep any CSS adjustments from outside from affecting at least the dimensions of the outer element, and that seems to be the vector for information leakage in all of these cases.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>

        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Another crazy idea: Could we hack the CSS style engine to not allow pseudo classes in some situations (i.e. when the text control element is in previous state)? If that was the case, would placeholder->style()->setProperty(GetExecutionContext(), "font", "-webkit-small-control", "important", ASSERT_NO_EXCEPTION); be sufficient because the style attribute would have the highest CSS specificity?<span class="line"><!---->Another crazy idea: Could we hack the CSS style engine to not allow pseudo classes in some situations (i.e. when the text control element is in previous state)? If that was the case, would placeholder-&gt;style()-&gt;setProperty(GetExecutionContext(), "font", "-webkit-small-control", "important", ASSERT_NO_EXCEPTION); be sufficient because the style attribute would have the highest CSS specificity?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>

        Rune is the best expert, but he's OOF for another week. Here's what I can suggest from the layout perspective.<span class="line"><!---->Rune is the best expert, but he's OOF for another week. Here's what I can suggest from the layout perspective.<!----></span><br><br>`::first-line` is probably a little different from other pseudo, because it depends on the layout result.<span class="line"><!---->`::first-line` is probably a little different from other pseudo, because it depends on the layout result.<!----></span><br><br>The lowest level entry of `::first-line` from the layout perspective is `LayoutObject::FirstLineStyleWithoutFallback`:<span class="line"><!---->The lowest level entry of `::first-line` from the layout perspective is `LayoutObject::FirstLineStyleWithoutFallback`:<!----></span><br>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/layout/layout_object.cc;l=4142;drc=0d99d5d1985df1f0788ccdaa43b34e8d248bf2c1;bpv=0;bpt=1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/layout/layout_object.cc;l=4142;drc=0d99d5d1985df1f0788ccdaa43b34e8d248bf2c1;bpv=0;bpt=1"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/layout/layout_object.cc;l=4142;drc=0d99d5d1985df1f0788ccdaa43b34e8d248bf2c1;bpv=0;bpt=1<!----></a><br><br>This seems to call `LayoutObject::GetUncachedPseudoElementStyle`, which calls `Element::StyleForPseudoElement`. Maybe either of these are good point to disable pseudo?<span class="line"><!---->This seems to call `LayoutObject::GetUncachedPseudoElementStyle`, which calls `Element::StyleForPseudoElement`. Maybe either of these are good point to disable pseudo?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Re <span class="line"><!---->Re <!----></span>#c22<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c22"><!---->#c22<!----></a>: yes, FrameOverlay paints on top of everything else. If it were modified to paint with the correct z-order, we'd be open to timing attacks that time subtle differences in how long it takes to apply filters on various inputs. These timing attacks are a much higher bar than getting data out of the DOM (e.g., timing is slow and unreliable), but we should probably investigate an approach that still paints above everything the page can control.<span class="line"><!---->: yes, FrameOverlay paints on top of everything else. If it were modified to paint with the correct z-order, we'd be open to timing attacks that time subtle differences in how long it takes to apply filters on various inputs. These timing attacks are a much higher bar than getting data out of the DOM (e.g., timing is slow and unreliable), but we should probably investigate an approach that still paints above everything the page can control.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">

        I have a prototype that seems to be working except for the ::first-line pseudo state: For ::first-line, the computed style of the shadow dom is correct (as per DevTools) but it is not applied.<span class="line"><!---->I have a prototype that seems to be working except for the ::first-line pseudo state: For ::first-line, the computed style of the shadow dom is correct (as per DevTools) but it is not applied.<!----></span><br><br>I believe that<span class="line"><!---->I believe that<!----></span><br>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/css/resolver/style_resolver.cc;l=1047;drc=9834395f60edc393922232e5194b4e299b6174e9<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/css/resolver/style_resolver.cc;l=1047;drc=9834395f60edc393922232e5194b4e299b6174e9"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/core/css/resolver/style_resolver.cc;l=1047;drc=9834395f60edc393922232e5194b4e299b6174e9<!----></a><br>may be the culprit. The passed element is a nullptr, so I cannot see that this has a ShadowPseudoId() == shadow_element_names::kPseudoInternalInputSuggested whose style should be overridden.<span class="line"><!---->may be the culprit. The passed element is a nullptr, so I cannot see that this has a ShadowPseudoId() == shadow_element_names::kPseudoInternalInputSuggested whose style should be overridden.<!----></span><br><br>I need to find a nice place to override the style. StyleAdjuster::AdjustComputedStyle or LayoutTheme::AdjustStyle looked nice, but I don't have the element to check whether to hard code the font and overflow properties.<span class="line"><!---->I need to find a nice place to override the style. StyleAdjuster::AdjustComputedStyle or LayoutTheme::AdjustStyle looked nice, but I don't have the element to check whether to hard code the font and overflow properties.<!----></span><br><br>Maybe andruud@ has an idea, who worked on this code recently.<span class="line"><!---->Maybe andruud@ has an idea, who worked on this code recently.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement.

      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }
      </style>

window.prpcClient = new AutoRefreshPrpcClient(
 CS_env.token, CS_env.tokenExpiresSec);

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });

 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {

 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });

  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;

    display: inline;

    background: none;
  }
  a, chops-button, a.button, .button, .linkify {
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;
    font-weight: var(--chops-link-font-weight);
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);
  }
  chops-button i.material-icons, a.button i.material-icons, .button i.material-icons {
    display: block;
    margin-right: 4px;
  }
  chops-button.emphasized, a.button.emphasized, .button.emphasized {
    background: var(--chops-primary-button-bg);
    color: var(--chops-primary-button-color);
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }
  .medium-heading chops-button {
    line-height: 1.6;
  }
  .input-grid {
    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        mr-app {
          display: block;
          padding-top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-top: -1px; /* Prevent a double border from showing up. */

          /* From shared-styles.js. */
          --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
          --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
          --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
          font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
          color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
        }
        main {
          border-top: var(--chops-normal-border);
        }
        .snackbar-container {
          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }
      <style>
        
  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
    --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
    --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
    color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /** Converts a <button> to look like an <a> tag. */
  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;
    background: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
  }
  h1, h2, h3, h4 {
    background: none;
  }
  a, chops-button, a.button, .button, .linkify {
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;
    font-weight: var(--chops-link-font-weight);
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);
  }
  chops-button i.material-icons, a.button i.material-icons, .button i.material-icons {
    display: block;
    margin-right: 4px;
  }
  chops-button.emphasized, a.button.emphasized, .button.emphasized {
    background: var(--chops-primary-button-bg);
    color: var(--chops-primary-button-color);
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }

    line-height: 1.6;
  }

    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        </div>
        
          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.
        <p>
          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.
        </p>
      <chops-dialog>
        <h2>
          Issue tracker keyboard shortcuts
          <button class="close-button">
            Close
          </button>
        </h2>
        <div class="keyboard-help">
          <!---->
            <div class="keyboard-help-section">
              <span></span><span class="help-title"><!---->Issue list<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->k<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator"> / </span>
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->j<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->up/down in the list<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->o<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator"> / </span>
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->Enter<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->open the current issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->Shift-O<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->open issue in new tab<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->x<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->select the current issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
            </div>
          <!---->
            <div class="keyboard-help-section">
              <span></span><span class="help-title"><!---->Issue details<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->k<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator"> / </span>
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->j<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->prev/next issue in list<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->u<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->up to issue list<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->r<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->reply to current issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->Ctrl+Enter<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator"> / </span>

                    <kbd><!---->⌘+Enter<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->save issue reply (submit issue on issue filing page)<!----></span>
              <!---->
            </div>
